newsitem.title: FRANCE: France denies Algerian GIA claimed train bombing.
newsitem.headline: France denies Algerian GIA claimed train bombing.

text.p: Interior Minister Jean-Louis Debre hinted in an interview on Monday that France had cleared Algeria's most ruthless Islamic rebel group of a 1996 bomb attack on a Paris commuter train in which four people died.

French officials had earlier said they believed that Algeria's deadly Armed Islamic Group (GIA) -- known as the GIA -- had claimed responsibility for the December 3 blast on the train as it pulled into Paris' Port Royal station.
But Debre told the French daily Le Figaro that the GIA had been misunderstood in a key communication and was instead claiming responsibility for 1995 attacks in France.
In an April article in the Arab newspaper Al Hayat, the GIA "said nothing about the Port Royal attack," Debre said in the interview, to be published in Le Figaro on Tuesday.

Asked about the status of France's investigation of the bombing, Debre said it had made progress "and we have been able to eliminate certain avenues put forward at the beginning of the investigation".
It was possible the bombing might be linked to unspecified gangsters and terrorists who were working together, he said.
But when asked whether that meant the GIA had been eliminated as a suspect in the blast, Debre responded: "You cannot deduce that from my remarks. One must not rule out any hypothesis".

Investigators have long been said to be working under the assumption that a series of bombing attacks in France during 1995 and 1996 were linked to fundamentalist rebels unhappy with France's tacit support for the Algerian authorities.
An estimated 60,000 people have died in civil violence in Algeria since the authorities canceled a 1992 election the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front was poised to win.
